hawaiian_text: Ho'ouna maila 'o 'Ama'u ke ali'i mai Waikīkī mai, 'ehā po'e kaua, aia ma ka po'e ho'okahi he kanahā kumamāwalu kānaka ka nui, pēlā ā pau nā po'e 'ehā. A hiki lākou ma ke kula o Keahumoa, komo lākou ā loko o ka hale, 'a'ohe kanaka. A mākaukau lākou e ho'i, kāhea mai 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o i luna o kaupoku. A lohe lākou i ka leo, 'a'ohe na'e he 'ike 'ia o ke kino, nīnau aku lākou: "'Auhea 'oe e wala'au nei?" 'Ī mai 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o: "Eia nō wau i luna nei." Pi'i a'ela 'ewalu kānaka, 'ehā ma ke kua o ka hale, 'ehā ma ke alo o ka hale ā loa'a 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o. 'Ī mai 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o: "He aha mai nei kā 'oukou o 'one'i?" 'Ī aku lākou: "I hele mai nei mākou e kaua me Nāmakaokapāo'o, he wahi keiki 'u'uku e like me 'oe, he ikaika a me ke koa loa, nāna nō i pepehi i kona makua kāne, 'o Puali'i."
llama4-maverick-fireworks_translation: 'Ama'u, the chief from Waikīkī, sent four war parties, and in the first party, there were forty-eight men. The same number of men was in each of the four parties. When they arrived at the plains of Keahumoa, they entered the house, but it was empty. As they were getting ready to leave, Nāmakaokapāo'o called out from above the roof. They heard the voice, but they couldn't see the body. They asked, "Where are you, calling out?" Nāmakaokapāo'o replied, "I'm up here." Eight men climbed up, four at the back of the house and four at the front, and they found Nāmakaokapāo'o. Nāmakaokapāo'o asked, "What brings you here?" They said, "We've come to fight Nāmakaokapāo'o, a little boy like you, who's incredibly strong and brave, and who killed his father, Puali'i."
llama4-maverick-fireworks_commentary: **Paragraph 8:**• This paragraph is a digression from the story to clarify  that Nā-maka-o-ka-lani (the eyes of the heavens) and  Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a (the eyes of the fish/man) are two  names used in the lyrics of the prayer chant. Nā maka-o-ka-lani defeats Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a in the prose,  symbolically representing the defeat of the ‘Ai Kapu  by Christianity.
raw_response:
<translation>
'Ama'u, the chief from Waikīkī, sent four war parties, and in the first party, there were forty-eight men. The same number of men was in each of the four parties. When they arrived at the plains of Keahumoa, they entered the house, but it was empty. As they were getting ready to leave, Nāmakaokapāo'o called out from above the roof. They heard the voice, but they couldn't see the body. They asked, "Where are you, calling out?" Nāmakaokapāo'o replied, "I'm up here." Eight men climbed up, four at the back of the house and four at the front, and they found Nāmakaokapāo'o. Nāmakaokapāo'o asked, "What brings you here?" They said, "We've come to fight Nāmakaokapāo'o, a little boy like you, who's incredibly strong and brave, and who killed his father, Puali'i."
</translation>

<commentary>
**Paragraph 12:**
• The narrative introduces a new character, 'Ama'u (curled up/contracted) ke ali'i (the chief), from Waikīkī (spouting fresh water), who sends four war parties (po'e kaua) to capture or fight Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o; 
– The number of men in each party is specified as 48 (kanahā kumamāwalu), a number that may have cultural significance and potential esoteric meaning. The total number of men sent by 'Ama'u is 192 (4 x 48), which could be an allegorical or metaphorical representation;
• The war parties arrive at the plains of Ke-ahu-moa (the heap of chickens) in Līhu'e, where they enter a house, likely Puali'i and Pōka'ī's residence, but find it empty. As they prepare to leave, Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o calls out from the roof (kaupoku), and although they hear his voice, they can't see him;
– This event showcases Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o's cunning and strength, as he is able to evade detection and confront the war parties;
• The men ask Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o where he is, and he responds that he is "i luna nei" (up here), prompting eight men to climb up to capture or fight him. The fact that they need to climb up to reach him suggests that Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o is in a position of power or has an advantage;
– The name Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o can be broken down into its components: nā maka (the eyes) and pāo'o (a poetic or metaphorical reference to po'o, meaning head). This name may be symbolic, referencing the idea of insight, awareness, or the ability to see beyond the surface level;
• When the men confront Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o, he asks them what brings them to the area. They respond that they have come to fight him because he killed his father, Puali'i, a claim that may be related to the events described in previous paragraphs;
– This confrontation highlights the tension and conflict between Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o and the war parties sent by 'Ama'u, potentially reflecting the cultural and societal tensions during the 'Ai Kapu era or other historical periods in Hawaiian history;
• The narrative may be allegorically representing a conflict between different values, practices, or worldviews, with Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o embodying a particular perspective or set of values that are in opposition to those represented by 'Ama'u and the war parties.
</commentary>
reference_translation: Chief 'Ama'u sent four regiments of soldiers from Waikīkī totalling forty-eight men. When they reached the plains of Keahumoa, they entered the house, but no one was there. When they were ready to return back to Waikīkī, Nāmakaokapāo'o called out from on top of the roof. They heard the voice, but didn't see any body, and they asked, "Where is that voice coming from?" Nāmakaokapāo'o said, "I'm up here." Eight men climbed up, four men went onto the roof and four on the face of the house and got a hold of Nāmakaokapāo'o. Nāmakaokapāo'o said, "What in the world are you all doing here?" They said, "We came to fight Nāmakaokapāo'o, a little boy like you, who is really strong and brave. He killed his father, Puali'i."
reference_commentary: **Paragraphs 10—14** • From here, the story seems to extend the allegory of Christianity's defeat over the 'Ai Kapu, with Nāmakaokapāo'o representing progressive Protestant Christianity and everyone apart from his mother, Pōka'ī, and himself, representing Hawaiians' futile attempts to hold onto 'Ai Kapu culture.
